title: Street Courts Rule
outcome: Grassroots assemblies seize momentum after the referendum stalemate, establishing neighborhood courts and local councils. These 'street courts' publicly review old BCI-related grievances, prosecute election tampering, and deliver varying sentences. A rush for closure creates inconsistencies and new grievances, deepening divisions. Meanwhile, returning formerly-flagged citizens face both forgiveness and backlash as some neighborhoods lean toward reconciliation, while others demand retribution. Central authority is sidelined, caught between public pressure for amnesty and demands for harsher justice.

events.description: Grassroots leaders organize public 'street courts,' inviting residents to present grievances about BCI abuses and the recent election chaos.
Some neighborhoods begin issuing sentences against former Council agents and ballot tamperers, ranging from community service to enforced exile.
Tensions escalate as verdicts vary widely between districts. Reconciliation ceremonies are held in some areas, but others descend into vendetta-fueled reprisals.
Returning citizens previously flagged by BCI confront divided communities—some welcome them, while others stage protests against perceived leniency.
The sidelined Council struggles to intervene, caught between the push for amnesty and demands for stricter justice, leaving true unity out of reach.
